runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is realistic fiction. It has characters like people students know, and events that could happen in real life.
Have students identify the main characters in the illustrations.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is an effect of doing something.
of recycling plastic instead of throwing it away?
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find a word in the third paragraph that has the schwa sound. (responsible)
What happens as a result of the pet swap? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are Michael and Sarahs experiences with each others pets the same? How are they different?
Have you ever cared for someone elses pet? What was it like?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this comic is about fruits and vegetables and when theyre in season. There are speech bubbles for each fruit and vegetable speaking.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means to ship and sell goods to another country. The prefix
means out, so these goods are taken out of our country.
tea to countries around the world.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the words that name the vegetables on the first page of the story. (asparagus, potato)
Which countries export bananas? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why do we get some foods from different places around the world? Summarize.
Which food in this text do you like best? Why?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with schwa /ə/ .
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 5 (period), 6 (question mark), and 7 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with emotion).
Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title. Explain that a tycoon is someone who is successful at business.
Have students share what they know about comics.
Remind them that they should pay attention to the illustrations as well as the speech bubbles.
For the first reading, have students read the boys speech bubbles while you read the grandfathers speech bubbles.
Then pair students to reread the text, with each partner reading for one character. Partners can switch roles during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all of the words with schwa and circle them.
Then have students chorally read the circled words.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read an informational text about taxes.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
three paintings to the art show.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the food word in the second paragraph that ends with the schwa sound. (pizza)
When do U.S. residents need to submit their taxes each year? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How is income tax different from sales taxes? Explain.
Are there any other services that you think our tax money should pay for?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with the schwa sound.
Then have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts.
For example, as you read sentence 3, pause briefly after aware.
Point out that the second group of words provides more detail about the previous group.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text includes a bar graph.
Have students identify what each bar in the graph represents.
Guide students through a reading of the text, including the bar graph.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when reading the text and looking at the bar graph.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a girl and her mom having a tag sale.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to believe that something will happen.
The weather forecast says that our area can
a lot of rain this weekend.
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the main character. (Alissa)
What is a tag sale? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What does Alissa expect from the tag sale? Does it meet her expectations? Explain.
Do you agree that people love tag sales? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat.
Explain that this informational text is about a girl who invented a new product.
Have students use the title and pictures to identify the product.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means a new idea, or a better way of doing something.
that changed the way people communicate, or talk.
Which invention has had the greatest effect on the way we live? Why was it an important
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the inventor that the text is mostly about. (Alina Morse)
How did Alina get the idea for her invention? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How did Alina develop her product? Summarize the process.
Would you describe Alinas lollipop as an innovation? Why or why not?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
